Award.AwardTitle: 2013-2014 Clifford Lectures: Local and Nonlocal, Deterministic and Stochastic Evolution Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract (Zhao, 1342607):

This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of graduate students and postdocs to participate in the "2013-2014 Clifford Lectures" to be held on November 08-11, 2013, at Tulane University.

The event aims to bring together leading experts and researchers in nonlinear partial differential equations (both on the applied and theoretical sides). The list of speakers includes top mathematicians such as G. Iyer, A. Kiselev, N. Masmoudi and E. Titi. The audience will consist of the participants from various universities and institutions in Louisiana and the New Orleans area, as well as other parts of the United States and abroad, such as, Loyola University, Xavier University, University of New Orleans, Louisiana State University, University of Louisiana, Princeton University, Stanford University, and Simon Fraser University and University of British Columbia. The organizers anticipate the participation of minority scholars. This is a high impact conference for the region of Louisiana.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2013-2014 Clifford Lectures took place on November 8-11, 2013 at Tulane University in New Orleans, Louisiana. It was a four-day series of lectures delivered by Peter Constantin (the Clifford Lecturer), a William R. Kenan, Jr. Professor of Mathematics and Applied and Computational Mathematics, and Director of Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics (PACM) at Princeton University, and nine talks given by invited speakers selected by the Clifford Lecturer. The theme of the lectures was "Local and Nonlocal, Deterministic and Stochastic Evolution Equations", which encompasses many important and active research areas in analysis, nonlinear partial differential equations (PDE), mathematical fluid dynamics and mathematical physics. The primary goal of the conference was to bring together scientists and mathematicians working in analysis, PDE and related fields. Contemporary challenges raised by recent advances in engineering, industry, and bio-technology, were confronted during the conference with state-of-the-art mathematical tools in analysis and PDE. The conference also aimed to introduce problems related to PDE, fluid dynamics and mathematical physics to a general audience in Louisiana and the New Orleans area, and to engage graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.

Local and nonlocal, deterministic and stochastic evolution equations, such as the Euler/Navier-Stokes equations and the surface quasi-geostrophic equation, are important mathematical models describing the motion of fluids, gas and waves. The topics that were presented at the conference concentrated on problems for large solutions, nonlinear waves and realistic models in multiple spatial dimensions. These situations often involve complicated but interesting phenomena resulting from nonlinearity and coupling, and thus are under-developed. Rigorous analysis of these problems is mathematically challenging. Better understanding of analytical solutions plays an important role in the understanding of core issues in science and engineering, such as the onset of turbulence, formation of boundary layer, wave propagation in combustion, geophysical fluid dynamics and mathematical biology.

A support from the NSF allowed to turn the 2013-2014 Clifford Lectures into one of the major scientific events at Tulane University and in the city of New Orleans. Conference participats consisted of 60 scholars, including faculty, postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and minority scholars, from the universities and institutions in Louisiana and the New Orleans area, as well as other parts of the United States and abroad. The theme and the format of the conference (4 main lectures + 9 invited one-hour talks) allowed to make most of the talks accessible for the faculty, postdoctoral researchers and graduate students in both pure and applied mathematics. A wide range of applications that were discussed at the conference made it truly interdisciplinary. Research collaborations took place among conference participants. Moreover, the theme of the conference is an under-developed research field in Louisiana, especially in the New Orleans area. The success of the conference boosted research and educational activities in this challenging research field in Louisiana and the New Orleans area. The success of the conference has attracted one postdoctoral scholar, Vincent Martinez (graduated from Indiana University - Bloomington), to Tulane University, will continue helping attract high-quality graduate students and postdoctoral scholars to this region of the United States in the near future.
